text: Establish "STEDMAN FIELD" stadium. . The stands are PACKED with CHEERING FANS.
(voice-over) It was the all-state high school championship game. Bottom of the ninth, two out. PLAYERS in both dugouts are straining forward, SHOUTING. The PLAYERS on the field are in tight.
(voice-over) Fenwick was standing on third like it was getting set to explode under his feet. A 15 year-old, FENWICK, is anxiously poised on third base

(voice-over) Fillmore High had us by a run, and it was a 3-1 count. The championship had come down to one batter: yours truly, Larry Burrows. LARRY BURROWS, 15 years of age, is at home plate waiting for the pitch. He spits, but it catches on his chin. He wipes it off and glances sheepishly at the catcher. The TEAM COACH, 35, is pacing in the dugout. (CONTINUED)
Let’s go, Larry! Swing away, swing away! You can do it, Larry! Watch the infield, babe! There is an intense look of concentration on Larry’s face

(voice-over) Haskins was throwing fastballs, because that was the only pitch he ever threw...so I was ready for the next one. The Pitcher, JERRY HASKINS, 16, winds up and throws. Larry swings: CRACK! A towering fly, going deep! Looks il it’s out of the park.
(voice-over) I swung perfect, got great wood, and hung it up there like it was heading for Mars. A ROAR from the crowd. But no! No! NO! It curves foul! By mere inches!

(voice-over) Then this gust of wind came up outa nowhere and nudged it foul. I swear to God, a gust of wind! Larry steps out of the batter’s box, frustrated. The scoreboard turns over: 3 and 2. Larry twists the bat in his hands, getting a good grip. The players in Larry’s dugout strain forward. CLIP METZLER, a curly-haired 15-year old nerd, and the resident "bench-warmer", leans out of the dugout, clappin
Paste it, Lare! You can do it! c’mon, Lare! Have-an-eye, have-an-eye, have~an-eye, soo-wing, babe! (CONTINUED)
Larry steps back into the box, digs his sneakers into the dirt, sets the bat, and squints down at the pitcher, look tough.

(voice-over) Why is it, when you do something terrific, nine times outa ten, you’re all alone? But when you screw up really big...the whole world is watching? The crowd is on its feet with anticipation. Haskins goes into his wind-up and throws. SLOW MOTION: the ball breaks RIGHT AT THE CAMERA, straigh and hard, coming closer and closer and closer. LARRY’S POV: As the ball hurtles towards him, a SWELL OF LIGHT SEEMS TO EMERGE FROM BEHIND IT. Larry blinks. - The ball closes in. Larry swings with all his might. The ball THUDS LIKE A THUNDERCLAP into the catcher’s mitt

Steeee-rike Thur-eeee!!! Larry‘’s swing twists him around and he falls in the dirt Silence. The crowd stares in disappointment and horror. (MOS) The other team races out onto the field and hoists Haskins on their shoulders. Larry sits up, wiping dirt off his face and winces with t pain of failure and shame.
(voice-over) It was a perfect pitch. A pitch from God. Had my name all over it. And I missed. I really missed.
INT. LARRY’S GARAGE ~ DAY (1990) - LARRY, now 35, is in his garage workshop, staring into space, lost in thought. (CONTINUED)

I still can’t get over it. I was sure I/d hit it. It was like the ball went right through the bat! (breaking his reverie) Ever have anything like that happen to you, Sammy? Re looks down at his MONGREL DOG, SAMMY, for an answer. T dog stares back attentively and BARKS.

Here. Looks like you could use one of these.
Oh, thanks. I must have gotten something in my eye...all the dust and stuff... ELLEN . Yeah, there is alot of dust blowing around. Larry dabs his eyes then hands the handkerchief back.
Thanks.
It’s okay, you can keep it. I got lots. My aunt sends me six dozen every Christmas. (CONTINUED)
Larry looks at the handkerchief TO SEE the initials EJR.
What’s E.J.R.?
Ellen Jane Ripley. What’s your name?
Larry. Larry Joseph Burrows. They shake hands. She smiles at him.
Nice to meet you, Larry.
(o.8.) ‘ Larry! eo INT. LARRY’S GARAGE DAY (1990) * Larry is looking at the handkerchief with the faded initi EIR.
la , (o.s.} rry! He comes out of his reminiscence and turns to SEE: A WOMA standing in the doorway. It’s the adult version of the 16 year-old girl in the flashback.

(gently) Yeah, we heard... EXT. LARRY’S HOUSE DAY Establish the house: a partially-built modest home in a n subdivision. Larry comes out of the garage to meet GUZELMAN, a 300 lb Armenian, who munches a jelly donut and sips a coffee.
(good~naturedly) Hey, Mr. Guzelman! How’re you? Haven’t seen you the past six weeks. Thought you’d been captured by aliens.

Well, if I give you another check, when do you think you’1ll get around to doing the work?

Thousand.
Don’t you guys know any other number?
Two thousand. LARRY b Okay, okay, a thousand. v Larry quickly writes out a check.
Couldja at least gimme a rough estimate of what "soon" means. Is that next week? Next month? Sometime this century?
Soon. . Guzelman grabs the check and gets into his truck.
Sure ya won’t stay for breakfast? Guzelman backs his truck out of the driveway, splattering mud on Larry.
Try cashin’ that check, ya fat piece a crap. The truck slides to a halt.
Wuzzat?!

~11~ INT. LARRY‘S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM DAY Larry enters, sorting through the mail.
